talk.start.para: . -I am conscious of the fact that the subject before the House for debate, the matter of international affairs and foreign relations, is possibly the most complex and difficult that one could address himself to. I am also conscious that to speak on this subject involves a great sense of responsibility, and that the individual should express his views irrespective of the consequences and irrespective of the popularity of the comments that he might make. I believe that the peoples of the world,' irrespective of their religious political philosophies and modes of life, seek the four great freedoms which were so well phrased by the great Churchill and the great Roosevelt when they announced that they and the allied troops were fighting for freedom of worship, freedom from fear, freedom from want and freedom of speech.

speech.para: At the moment honorable members and the Australian people are, by virtue of a chain of circumstances directly associated with this debate, more concerned with a search for freedom from fear. During the last few months I have realized, by reason of discussions at Geneva and in the United Nations, and by articles published in the press of the world, that the people of this and other countries have expressed a real fear that they are in danger. When the phrase " freedom from fear " was coined, it was designed to convey to the people that it should apply not only to Christians, but also to the people of all parts of the world. That is why I say that I hope that even the people who are directly, and by inference, considered to be our enemies, will eventually be placed in such a position as will enable us all to say that we shall, by every means at our disposal, endeavour to bring about freedom from fear, freedom from want, freedom of speech and freedom of worship throughout the world.

Anything that I might say in criticism of the policies of our great friends in the United States of America, and of our great friends and former allies of France, must not be considered to be other than a criticism of a very friendly nature. We look to those friends and allies to-day for further friendship and assistance, and they are very great people indeed and have the same Christian principles and outlook on life as we ourselves endeavour to preach and practice. During the long tedious course of this debate, all that the Government has put before us is an attitude. Indeed, no policy of any sort whatsoever has been placed before this Parliament. The Government has merely struck an attitude. It has brought to this House the outcome of the negotiations at Geneva, which have fortunately temporarily brought peace to the war-stricken part of Asia that is known as Indo-China. The Government has brought to the House the possibility of the formulation of a treaty, to be known as the SouthEast Asia Treaty Organization.

Most of the speakers on behalf of the Government, including Ministers, have addressed the House, intentionally or unintentionally, to the effect that already the Government is committed to a SouthEast Asia Treaty Organization. They have not emphasized that at the moment no such treaty, nor, indeed, any concrete proposals, have been brought forward for discussion; nor have they indicated to the House the nature of the conditions that would be contained in a treaty that they consider should be agreed to by this country, the Americas and any other friendly people who may be prepared to join us. The Government has allowed us to believe that we are already committed to a treaty. Let me inform the people that no such treaty exists. It is quite true that the Government has given this Parliament an assurance that when a treaty, which they have almost committed themselves to in advance, has actually been formulated, it will be submitted to the Parliament for its approval. I repeat that the Government has lead the people to believe that a document actually exists, that proposals are in evidence and that now all that requires to be done at a later stage is to put on the table of this Parliament a treaty which contains certain written obligations on the part of Australia, the. Americas, parts of Indo-China possibly, and other friendly countries, and say " We have consulted our Parliament ". What they really mean to say is that they have confronted us with a fait accompli. The Government will say " We have the numbers so through the Parliament it goes ". Then the people will find that they are possibly committed to an obligation to send troops, arms, naval vessels, aircraft and war materials to the mainland of Asia under the terms of the so-called South-East Asia Treaty Organization.

talk.start.para: - No one understands the position better than the honorable member.

- The honorable member need not interject. I am not without some knowledge of what happens with regard to international agreements and treaties. I recollect the negotiations that took place in regard to the Internationa] Wheat Agreement. Australian ministers and their deputies meet the ministers and deputies of other countries. They concoct an arrangement and then go back and say to their Parliaments' " We have agreed as a government to be a party to an international agreement" and then, at the last moment, they throw the agreement on to the tables of their parliaments for discussion. They are involved in what is in effect a fait accompli. Of course in those circumstances no parliament has any other alternative, because of the superior numbers of Government members, but to give effect to the Government's arrangement.
- Did the honorable member do that?
- I do not intend to answer stupid questions.
- Order ! The honor.able member should not answer interjections.

- I suggest that the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir Eric Harrison) has no right to interject while I am speaking. The tenor of this debate is that something is already in existence. The Government has not said directly that a treaty organization exists, but the people believe that there is some arrangement already in operation. The Government has a duty to make it quite clear to those people that no treaty yet exists. It also has an obligation to indicate now, quite clearly and unequivocally, the nature of the agreement that it will be willing to sign. I know the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Casey) will say that the subject matter that the proposed treaty is to contain will be hammered out in consultation with our friends in America and the United Kingdom. But we want to know now what this Government believes should go into that treaty, and what obligations the Government expects this country to undertake. I make that statement with particular emphasis, because I believe that despite our small population, and because of our geographical position and the influence of our opinions on world opinion in the past, it is not beyond the realms of possibility that if we were to express concise propositions in this Parliament, and if they were to be wisely phrased by the Government and wisely conveyed to our friends and allies, our representations would have great influence.

speech.para: T have emphasized my friendship for the American people, and therefore I can say that everybody knows that at present speeches are being made and propaganda is being issued in the Americas about the policy that the world, and in particular those countries involved in SouthEast Asia, should, follow. There is a belief in some parts of America that in order to contain communism, the American peoples should have a foothold on the soil of Asia. There are people who believe that nationals in Asia should be deprived of their right to determine whether they will accept communism or otherwise. Indeed, I believe that that, opinion is very prevalent in the Americas. It is my firm opinion that we have a right to our political philosophies and a right to adhere to our great democratic system, which is the best system of government the world has known. But I remind honorable members that in World War I. we fought for the right of all people to seK-determination within the confines of their own territories. In those circumstances, if the nationals of a particular country decide that, because of the failure of other forms of government in their country, they desire to institute a philosophy or form of government that is alien and hateful to us, surely it is their right to do so.

I believe that we should indicate to all the peoples of the world, including those in America, that as far as we are concerned - and I pay tribute to some honorable members on each side of the House for their speeches in this regard - we are not in favour of one Australian foot being put on the Asian continent in order to prevent people who are anxious to get rid of all European domination from exercising that which they believe is their inherent right - the right to selfdetermination. We should say quite frankly that we do not believe that Australian battleships and destroyers, and Australian aircraft, should not enter Asian waters and Asian skies to prevent that selfdetermination. In the past, unlike the Chifley Government, this Government has shown evidence that it has no foreign policy. During this debate honorable members, including the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) himself, have admitted that the trouble that has occurred in South-East Asia and Indo-China is largely due to an upsurge of nationalism, and that we should have sympathy with those people in their attempt to assert their nationalism. The Government has also said that communism has used these nationalist movements as a vehicle to get control of, or play a part in, the governments of those countries. But this Government does not tell us that while these people were engaged in an upsurge of nationalism against the great French people in Indo-China, the Australian Government was sending arms and munitions of war to the French in order to help them to destroy those people who were indulging in an upsurge of nationalism.

talk.start.para: - Hear, hear !

- The honorable member for Henty (Mr. Gullett) says " Hear, hear ! ". He says, in effect that ha was a party to the actions of the MenziesFadden coalition when it shipped to Indo-China arms and all the other impedimenta of war in order to shoot down the people who were seeking nothing more than that about which the honorable member prates when he speaks of his service in World War I., that is, the right of people to self determination.
- That is plain nonsense.

- I do not expect the right honorable gentleman to .bring himself into line with policies that have been pursued with such marked success by the United Kingdom in Pakistan, India, Burma, and Ceylon - of course, I pay tribute to our enemies on the other side of this House for their participation in the Colombo plan - because those countries which comprise a very large section of Asia's population form part of the British Commonwealth. Those nations, to a greater degree than the Australian Government, comprise one of the greatest influences in the preservation of world peace that we have known. The Minister for External Affairs recently returned from Geneva. At Geneva, M. Mendes-France, who proved himself to be a very great statesman indeed, has been able to achieve those things that the mass of the French people, and particularly the workers of France, have wanted for a long time. The French people have been led to appreciate that they cannot continue to succeed in suppressing the people of Indo-China by force of arms and the imposition of the French form of government. M. Mendes-France, with the support of a section of his government, has been responsible for the endorsement of a policy of selfdetermination for the people of Indo-China.

speech.para: I stated that the people of Australia have not been presented with a concrete foreign policy since the Chifley Government was in office. If anybody wishes to have evidence in support of that statement, let him take up the fine book that contains the speeches of the late Mr. J. B. Chifley and let him also read the speeches of the present Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt). The book which contains the speeches of the late Mr. Chifley sets out clearly and concisely that the Australian Labour party supports the policy that Asia should be retained for the Asians, and -that Australia should devote its time, its energy and its wealth to encouraging those people to raise themselves to a higher standard of living. That book also points out that the Australian Labour party is of the opinion that Australia should not pursue a policy, such as the Government would pursue to-morrow, that would support people who may be prepared to pour into Asia millions of men and much money and treasure that would be lost irretrievably. I make those statements with a due sense of responsibility. Government supporters have suggested that Australia should offer economic aid to the people of Asia. Some weeks ago I wrote an article in which I suggested that the Government should send 50,000,000 bushels of wheat to Asia, because at the end of November, 1954, Australia will have a surplus of 100,000,000 bushels. I suggested that the Government should purchase the wheat from the farmers at a cost of £32,000,000, although that course may require a retention of the present rate of taxation. The Minister for External Affairs stated that the people of Asia were rice eaters and that they would eat wheat only in extremis. Does the right honorable gentleman, as an intelligent person, believe that, although those people are rice-eaters, ,they would not be glad to supplement their diet with some wheaten product, enjoy it, and become more responsible citizens of their country ?

talk.start.para: - Order ! The honorable member's time has expired.

.- The honorable member for Lalor (Mr. Pollard) has treated the House to a good deal of rhetorical rubbish. Very few of his statements require a reply. He charged the Government with having no foreign policy. On the face of it, that statement is complete nonsense. The foreign policy of the Government has been explained very clearly on more than one occasion by the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Casey). To put it in a nutshell, the foreign policy of this country is to make friends with its neighbours and to ensure its own security. That statement of policy covers all of the policy actions of the Government. The suggestion of the honorable member for Lalor that the Government, by its policy, is frustrating those people in South-East Asia who wish to determine their own destiny or who, to use his own words, are seeking self-determination, also is nonsense. The Government will encourage by every possible means, as its actions have already shown, the self-government and self-determination of any people. It has no intention of interfering with the domestic affairs of any nation, provided the domestic affairs of that nation are not shaped towards an end which threatens the security of Australia. To say that the difficulties and troubles in Indo-China are purely national is to close one's eyes to the provable facts. The difficulties and troubles in Indo-China are patently Communist inspired. As such, they are a threat to our own national security.

speech.para: The sending of arms to Indo-China was a proper action which was not intended to assist the French people to suppress any national movement but to assist in the defence of Australia against Communist aggression. It is inevitable that, in a debate of this kind, there will be much repetition in sense, if not in words. The international situation is such that Australia's very existence is threatened. That threat is obvious to any thinking Australian, but I do not believe that the Australian people as a whole appreciate the significance of the agreement that was recently reached between the French and the Communist forces in Viet Nam. Even at the risk of repetition, it is appropriate that I should trace very briefly a chain of events that may flow from the cessation of hostilities in Indo-China. The Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) has already warned us that we would be foolish indeed if we thought that the cease-fire in .Indo-China meant an end of the intentions of the Communist aggressors. The agreement provides that there shall be a general election in Viet Nam in 1956. If the result of that election were unfavorable to the democracies and if Viet Nam became a Communist State, which is within the realms of probability, and if Laos and Cambodia were overrun, the only remaining buffer State between Communist imperialism and Burma and Malaya would be Siam. Burma is a tempting bait to the Communists in their quest for world domination, because it is an important rice-growing country and, as such, must have an important effect upon the political and economic policies of the countries of South-East Asia. The occupation of Burma by Communist forces would be a direct threat to India. On the other hand, the conquest of Malaya, which is also a tempting bait to the Communists, would enable the Chinese to obtain substantial supplies of tin and rubber. The Chinese are largely dependent upon Russian resources. The fact that they dislike that dependence is revealed in their plans for industrial expansion. They are in great need of raw materials and, to some degree, Malaya could satisfy that need. Unless the Communist objective is greatly modified, we can expect the Communists to include Malaya on their list.

If Malaya is overrun, it is difficult to see how Indonesia can survive. Indonesia, which is rich in rubber and oil, also is a tempting bait to the Communists. The Indonesians are likely to become half-willing victims. Communist propaganda in support of an upsurge of nationalism, particularly propaganda that would inevitably raise the cry, " Western New Guinea for the Indonesians ", probably would raise much enthusiasm in the Indonesian people. If western New Guinea fell into Communist hands, how long do honorable members think that the Territory of Papua and New Guinea would remain under our control in spite of possible intervention by the United Nations ? If that chain of' events took place, the penultimate situation would be that the Chinese Communists would sit at Port Moresby and look down the Queensland coast. That is a line of aggression that may be pursued by the Communists, and against which we must guard while we have time. Our best military safeguards lie in some form of collective pact. For that reason, the Government has proposed and has subscribed to the establishment of a South-East Asia Treaty Organization, on the lines of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But military preparation is not all that is required. In this regard I agree wholeheartedly with honorable members from both sides of the chamber who have addressed themselves to the subject. At this stage, it is vital that in addition to making military preparations we shall develop friendly relations with those nations of South-East Asia that are not already engulfed by the Communist forces, and that we shall also ensure that they realize the advantages of self-government, compared with slavery under communism, and exercise correctly the right that the United Nations, the United States of America, Australia and all other democratic countries will endeavour to guarantee for them - the right to self-determination of their own affairs. I emphasize that that action must be taken now.

Australia's first line of defence is in Malaya, where, if necessary, we must stand and fight. It will be much easier and much more economical to assure the defence of Malaya if we preserve the integrity of Siam, the only completely independent state remaining between Malaya and Communist-dominated territory. In the best interests of peace we should immediately make it abundantly clear to the Chinese Communists that any threat to Siam will be regarded as a direct and immediate threat to Malaya, and, in consequence, as a direct threat to Australia. Holding these views as strongly as I do, I . was particularly interested to hear from the Prime Minister last Thursday evening that Australia had at last abandoned phantom military planning. By that I mean that, contrary to past policy, when we make military plans in the future we must, at the time those plans are made, consider commitments to back them with force, and not leave those commitments to be determined at some indefinite future date. I trust that those commitments will be substantial. I say so, because, as is well appreciated by all honorable members, no nation, not even the great United States of America, can defend itself alone. We all, ' great and small powers alike, are dependent for our security to some degree upon the support of our friends and allies, and Australia, in the situation peculiar to it, is probably more dependent upon its friends than is any other of the Western democracies. We must convince our friends that we are sincere and honest in our professed intention to defend ourselves. At present we have not succeeded in doing that. It is apparent from our defence expenditure that our efforts are badly lagging behind those of other nations. Defence expenditure in the United Kingdom is approximately .45 per cent, of the total' budget expenditure. In the United States of America it is about 70 per cent, of the total budget expenditure. In Australia, however, defence expenditure amounts to less than 20 per cent, of the total budget expenditure. This being so, we cannot prevent some niggling criticism occurring among our best friends. We look to them to defend us, but we are not ready to put forward anything like as great an effort as they are making on our behalf.

talk.start.para: -. Fraser. - Australia is a rapidly developing country.

- I appreciate that, and I realize that we probably cannot afford to expend on defence an amount equal to 70 per cent, of the budget expenditure, but I point out that there is a great difference between 20 per cent, and 70 per cent. I am sure that we can do much better than 20 per cent. I trust that when the question of commitments comes under consideration, as it must and should do, we shall be more generous than we have been in the past. I trust that if the occasion arises^ - I do not know whether it will - the Australian Government will propose that Australia, as an independent nation within the British Commonwealth, should volunteer to undertake the responsibility for the defence of Malaya. I do not refer to full-scale defence in war-time, which obviously would be well beyond our capacity, nor do I think for one moment that Australia could assume unaided the responsibility for maintaining the peacetime garrison that is necessary in Malaya in present circumstances. The United Kingdom at present does not undertake alone the provision of the peace-time garrison needed in Malaya. It calls on its friends for assistance, and Australia has answered that call by contributing to the defence of Malaya. Should we not be justified in making a similar call on our friends for help if we accepted responsibility for the defence of Malaya, which concerns our very existence more than it does that of any other Western '1 democracy ?
- Would the honorable member leave Australia undefended?

- Should we not be justified in asking Great Britain, the United States of America and the nations that it is proposed shall subscribe to Seato, to help us should we assume responsibility for the defence of Malaya? It may be that Australia's contribution will be so small that such an arrangement would be impossible, but at least we should make the offer and emphasize our good intentions and our willingness to defend ourselves to the utmost of our ability. If we were to expend on defence as large a proportion of the budget expenditure as is devoted to defence purposes by the United States of America, or even the United Kingdom, the proposal would not be so fantastic as it seems at the moment. In this debate suggestions that Australia should not send forces abroad have come from honorable members on both sides of the House. The honorable member for Dalley (Mr. Greenup) a moment ago asked whether I would leave Australia undefended. My reply is that the consequences will be nothing short of national suicide if we devote our military resources to the strengthening of defence forces in Australia and complacently sit behind them until we are attacked within our own territory. Our first line of defence at present lies in Malaya, and not in Australia. It might be inferred from what I have said that I place more emphasis on the military aspect of this problem than on the economic aspect, but I do not intend to convey that impression. Every one knows from experience that it is impossible to come to terms or to bargain with the Soviet and Communist powers except from a position of strength. Consequently, economic measures against communism are likely to be nullified unless the democracies can back them with strength in the form of military preparedness. It is necessary, therefore, that the two instruments of military and economic measures for our defence be used in conjunction. We should do much better to fight hopefully in Malaya than forlornly in Queensland.

.- The fact that for more than three years the House has not been allowed to participate in a debate on foreign affairs is a damning indictment of the Government. The last debate of any length on a ministerial statement on foreign affairs occurred on the 10th July, 1951, and occupied two hours and 40 minutes. On the 6th May, 1952, a statement on international affairs by the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Casey) was debated for a mere eighteen minutes. The next statement on international affairs by the Minister that was debated at all was made on the 5th September, 1952.
- Before the House had the advantage of the honorable member's presence !

- Things have improved in the meantime. The Minister's statement on that occasion related to the first meeting of the Anzus council, which had taken place a month before. The statement was not debated until a year later, when the second meeting of the Anzus council was in progress. The Minister for External Affairs has made other statements on Korea, meetings of the United Nations General Assembly, and the like. None of those statements was debated, and all were allowed to lapse with the prorogation of the Parliament. During the last week the House has had the good fortune to hear statements, first, by the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) on foreign affairs, and, secondly, by the Minister for External Affairs on SouthEast Asia. We have had the even better fortune to hear the Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) debate both those statements. This is virtually the first time in three years that the elected representatives of the people have had the opportunity to express their views on international affairs for the Government's consideration, and it is the first occasion in more than three years that the Government has deigned to listen to the views of the people's representatives on this matter.

speech.para: In the exciting and rapid movement of events during the last few months the Minister for External Affairs has twice circumnavigated the globe in the steps of his model, Mr. Eden, and his master, Mr. Dulles. Though the Minister saw fit to make statements to the newspapers in the United States of America and in other parts of the world, he did not say anything to the Australian press. The only Minister who has seen fit to make any statement on international affairs has been, of all people, the PostmasterGeneral (Mr. Anthony), who three weeks ago addressed the annual conference of the Queensland branch of the Australian Country party. In haranguing that rally of rustics the Postmaster-General declared that we Australians cannot live in peaceful co-existence with the Communists in this cold war. That pronouncement, fortunately, was in direct contradiction of statements that had already been made by President Eisenhower, of the United States of America, and Sir Winston Churchill, the British Prime Minister. The declaration of the PostmasterGeneral has been emphatically repudiated in this House by the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. As a consequence of that rash utterance, the Postmaster-General, whose health in recent months was deemed to be rapidly qualifying him for a diplomatic post, has rendered himself persona non grata to every head of State except President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea, and General Chiang Kai-shek, the leader of the Chinese Nationalist Government.

For the first time since Japan invaded Manchuria, there is peace on the continent of Asia, and for the first time since World War I. began 40 years ago, there is peace throughout the world. During the last three days honorable members have exercised their minds in recrimination and soul-searching at this unwonted state of affairs, and many honorable members have criticized the French, who they allege have let the free world down, and also the action of the Chinese Communist Government in intervening in Indo-China. I want to make my position in this matter perfectly plain. 1 do not blame the French one jot. Their gallantry in the seven and a half years during which they carried on the struggle in Indo-China cannot be denied. They may have been ill-advised. I certainly believe that they were, but it does not become any of us to criticize the forlorn hope of Dien Bien Phu. We can recall that Indian summer of French colonial glory when General de Lattre de Tassigny restored the French position temporarily and was, posthumously, awarded the grandest military title in the world - Marshal of France. At the same time, it is useless for us to blame the Chinese for intervening. China was not the only country to intervene in Indo-China. The Chinese were the first to recognize Ho-Chi-Minh as the head of State in Viet Nam. In fact, when the nationalists took over the occupation of northern Viet Nam, after the Japanese were defeated, Chiang Kai-shek recognized him in September, 1945, and armed him with Japanese arms. The French recognized Ho-Chi-Minh in March, 1946, and later that year negotiated with him at Fontainebleau. The French broke with him in December, 1946. It was in December, 1949, that Chinese troops reached the Viet Nam border. For the first three years of the war, Ho-Chi-Minh did not receive, because he could not receive, any help from Mao-Tse-Tung. Until the elections are held in Viet Nam in 1956 there will continue to be turmoil in that area. The tragedy is that those elections will be the first ever to be held in Indo-China.

Australia faces the dilemma that if war comes and Australia is attacked, the only country that can render it any assistance is the United States of America. Yet the policies very often advocated by that country are in complete disagreement with those advocated and acted upon by all our neighbours. I am not suggesting that we should take notice, to the point of action, of everything that leaders of Congress and of the American armed forces say. President Eisenhower has followed a middle course, and in view of public opinion in the United States of America one must admire him for following a sane and consistent course. It is unfortunate that the separation of legislative and executive functions in the United States of America relieves members of the American Congress of taking responsibility for their utterances. It is also unfortunate that Admirals Radford, Carney and Stump are not members of a silent service. The solution that is often suggested for the dilemma in which we find ourselves is that we should join a South-East Asia treaty organization on the analogy of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization which has experienced considerable success in the northern hemisphere in stemming the march of communism in that area. But although the United States of America, the United Kingdom probably, and ourselves are prepared to join such an organization, none of our neighbours are prepared to do so. India has certainly said that it will not join, and Indonesia and Burma have taken a similar stand, whilst Ceylon has said that it will follow India. Pakistan has said that it will attend a conference on the proposed organization, but that country has not committed itself to join the organization. The temper of those countries is reflected in a statement that was made last month by the Indonesian Foreign Minister when he said -

quote.para: Such a regional defence community in Asia should bc initiated by Asian powers themselves. For Asian countries the problem was how best to develop a. common defence based on unity of interest.

speech.para: If the South-East Asia Treaty Organization is to be valid at all, it must represent South-East Asia, but it cannot be said that the organization will represent that area if the only Asian countries that join it are the Philippines and Thailand. That fact has been publicly acknowledged in the Philippines in a statement that was made two weeks ago by Senator Claro Recto, the Nationalist Government's foreign policy spokesman. He said -

quote.para: An alliance excluding India, Indonesia, Pakistan, Burma and Ceylon will not be representative of South-East Asia.

speech.para: Thailand is of particular significance, because it may well be the country in which the next civil war, as some people would call it, or subversion, as other people would call it, may break out. The reason is that Thailand has a great Chinese minority which presents all the makings of a civil war, whilst coups d'etat have characterized politics in the country in recent years. Fearful of the number and skill of the Chinese in Thailand, the country has been opposed to the Governments of Chiang Kai-shek and of Mao-Tse-Tung, and successive Thai governments have sought the assistance of outside powers to counterbalance the Chinese influence. Just as Japan provided that bulwark for Thailand during the war, the United States of America serves that purpose in the interests of Thailand to-day.

One great fault of the South-East Asian Treaty Organization compared with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization secured the support and co-operation of the government of every country on both sides of the North Atlantic seaboard, with the exception of Spain and Eire, and it also obtained the co-operation of the maritime powers of the Mediterranean. So, all the relevant countries were represented in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization; and for that reason it has been successful. Conversely, if all the relevant countries are not represented in the South-East Asia Treaty Organization the organization will not be a success, and we shall only delude ourselves in joining any organization of that kind in such circumstances.

Certain phases of our policy have been allowed to continue for four and a half years to the provocation of the people of China and of all our neighbours. I refer to the question of the recognition of the

Communist Government in China and to its admission to the United Nations. Whether we like it or not, all of the Colombo plan nations have recognized the Government that is installed in Peking. At Colombo, on the 1st May last, the Prime Ministers of those five countries, four of which are members of the United Nations whilst the fifth, Ceylon, has failed to gain membership because of the exercise of the veto by Soviet Russia, said in a joint communique -

quote.para: The representation of the People's Republic of China, the Prime Ministers felt, would promote stability in Asia, ease world tension and assist in bringing about a more realistic approach to problems concerning the world, particularly in the Far East.

speech.para: It cannot be said that any of those countries are Communist-inclined, because in the same communique those five Prime Ministers stated -

quote.para: The Prime Ministers- affirmed their faith in democracy and .democratic institutions and, being resolved to preserve in their respective countries the freedoms inherent in a democratic system, declared their unshakable determination to resist interference in the affairs of their countries by external communist, anti-communist or other agencies.

speech.para: We have to face the fact that the countries of South-East Asia, and the Colombo plan countries in particular, do not regard the Communist Government in China as being hostile to them. In those circumstances, they do not wish to aline themselves with either of the two power blocs as they regard them. A still more serious phase of our policy is that we say not only that the Communist Government in China is not, and should not be, the government of that country, but also, that the Nationalist Government in Formosa is, and should be, the government of China. We must recognize the fact that the government installed in Formosa has no chance of ever again becoming the government of China unless it is enabled to do so as a result of a third world war. When we say that that government should be the government of China we not only take an unrealistic view but a menacing one. The Australian Government should have recognized the Communist Government in China, in view of the fact that all our neighbours, including the colonial powers, Great Britain and the Netherlands, have recog nized it. We are menaced by the situation that exists in Formosa. The arrangements there have no international or United Nations sanction; and we must not allow it to be thought that if any attack is made on Formosa we shall regard such an attack as a cause for war.

One fact that has emerged from this debate is that every honorable member stands for democracy and the preservation of peace. Therefore, the next thing that we must do is to consider how best we can preserve our system of government, promote it in other countries and prevent war, because only war will subvert our system of government in Australia, It is significant that the only countries among our neighbours who can be regarded as recognizable democracies, because they have a parliamentary or congressional government, are the five countries which the English-speaking countries ruled before World War II. and freed after that conflict. The British parliamentary system has proved successful in India, Pakistan, Burma, and Ceylon whilst the congressional system has proved successful in the Philippines. A change of government has taken place in the lastnamed through ordinary constitutional processes. In these five countries communism is weakest. If we want to preserve peace and democracy in this area we must ensure that those countries enjoy self-government.' We must see that there is a will to. peace in that area. We must be neighbourly, and, at all times, adhere to the principles of the United Nations and to its processes. Our neighbours will be satisfied with that, and we, also, should be satisfied with it. I quote from a statement given to Reveille by General Carlos Romulo, the personal representative at Washington of the President of the Philippines and his predecessors. He said -

quote.para: If communism is to bc successfully fought in South-East Asia, the will to fight it must first be there.
That will cannot be created unless it can be shown that in combating Moscow's godless ideology, the Asians would win their freedom, plain and absolute.

speech.para: In that area we not only can but we also must adopt peaceful means of conducting our affairs. If self-government succeeds in that area, there will he peace and development. We must co-exist with our neighbours. The conflicts in Malaya and Indo-China were not reasons for our going to war. I conclude by quoting the conclusion of a speech made by Sir Winston Churchill in the debate that took place recently in the House of Commons on foreign affairs upon his return from his visit to President Eisenhower. Sir Winston said -

quote.para: In the speech which my right honorable friend the Foreign Secretary made in winding up the debate before our departure, he used, in speaking about the relations of the Communist and free worlds, the remarkable phrase " peaceful co-existence ". This fundamental mid far-reaching conception certainly had an influence upon some of our conversations at Washington, and I was very glad when I read after we had left that President Eisenhower had said that the hope of the world lies in peaceful co-existence of the Communist and non-Communist powers, adding also the warning, with which I entirely agree, that this doctrine must not lead to appeasement that compels any nation to submit to foreign domination.

The House must' not underrate the importance of this broad measure of concurrence in what was in this case the English-speaking world. What a vast ideological gulf there is between the idea of peaceful co-existence vigilantly safeguarded and a mood of forcibly extirpating the Communist fallacy and heresy. Tt is indeed a gulf. This statement is a recognition of the appalling character which war has now assumed and* that its fearful consequences go even beyond the difficulties and clangers of dwelling side by side with Communist States. Indeed I believe that this widespread acceptance of this policy may in the passage of years lead to the problems which divide the world being solved or solving themselves as so many problems do in a manner which will avert the mass destruction of the human race and give time, human nature and the mercy of God their chance to win salvation for us.

talk.start.para: .- The honorable member for Werriwa (Mr. Whitlam) severely chided members of the Labour party, and, incidentally, himself for the failure to take advantage of the numerous opportunities afforded to them by this Government to discuss international affairs. The honorable member complained that the Government had hot given the House an adequate opportunity in the last three years to debate foreign affairs. He listed numerous occasions when statements on inter national affairs had been presented to the House by the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) and the Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Casey). He may not know, and so I inform him, that it is the right of the Opposition to discuss, and to demand opportunities to discuss, those matters. Why have- not members of the Opposition done so? They find plenty of time to be obstructive on minor matters when they so desire, but they apparently have a disregard for serious matters. Opposition members may not realize the fact, but they have been severely caned by the honorable member for Werriwa.

speech.para: The honorable gentleman also spoke of the dilemma in which Australia finds itself as the result of recent events in South-East Asia. Of course, we are in a dilemma, and we shall continue to be in a dilemma as long as this country is divided on the fundamental issue of the circumstances in which we shall become involved in war. The cry of th.p Labour party is, " If we are attacked, what shall we do? " Are we to wait until Australia is involved in war, or are we to take action to ensure that war will not come to Australia? As long as the Opposition adopts its present attitude, I frankly see no salvation for this country from the menace that is coming to it.

Recognition of Communist China was mentioned by the honorable member for Werriwa. I should like to know whether his expression of opinion is the official opinion of the Australian Labour party on the granting of recognition to red China.

talk.start.para: - What if it is?

- If it is, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) will have to eat many of his words. In my opinion, the United Nations cannot recognize red China. It is an aggressor nation.' Last night, we had the privilege of hearing a speech by the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Keon), and I agreed with his statement that no nation should be allowed to retain the spoils of its aggression. I express my own humble opinion, and I think that it is the humane view, when I say that the granting of recognition to red China would virtually extend to that country our forgiveness and blessing for all that it bas done. The United Nations would suffer another ignominious defeat. Undoubtedly, the United Nations, in which the Leader of the Opposition places such great hope, has done a tremendous amount of work in various fields other than ensuring the security of various nations. Many countries looked to the United Nations for their security, and did not take defensive measures. What has happened to them? We guaranteed their independence, just as the Labour party desires Australia to guarantee the independence of India and the countries of South-East Asia. Despite a guarantee of independence, the Baltic States are now behind the iron curtain. The United Nations let the Communists take them.

speech.para: Intervention by the United Nations in Korea did not leave that country a free and entirely independent nation. The forces of the United Nations won battles in Korea but, in my humble opinion, the fact that the Communists hold one half of that country means that the United Nations suffered defeat. France' has lost a substantial part of Indo-China, and that is another defeat for the West, ls Australia to place all its trust in this international organization that guarantees the security of countries? 1 believe that a nation must take measures to secure its own freedom and independence. Even in this civilised and Christian country of Australia, force is still required to enforce the law. No one has yet managed to dispense with bolts and bars on his doors, or to discard strong rooms. A patrolling force is still required for the security of individuals and a patrolling force is still required for the security of nations, because the world has not yet become Utopia, in which such measures are not necessary.

talk.start.para: - What should be done with the United Nations in the meantime?

- The United Nations is doing a good job in other directions. I' rely upon the police for protection, but I believe that I must be able to help myself in an emergency until the police arrive. Australia is adopting a similar policy. The mistake made by Opposition mem bers is that they regard communism as a political ideology. It is nothing of the sort. Communism is the worst evil that the world has ever known. It will undermine Western civilization, unless it is checked, because it will take from us the things upon which our civilization is founded, such as our religion, our family life, and our belief in a Supreme Being. Communism is not a political ideology. It is something that comes from hell itself for the purpose of destroying the world, if it possibly can. That is how I regard communism, and, because it is so evil, I believe that any means are justified to scorch it out, or to make certain that it does not gain a footing here.
- What independence do nations get under communism?

- None whatever. Here in Australia, in this land of opportunity where we enjoy freedom and the greatest blessings of any country, we find communism in our midst. What hope, then, have we of fighting communism as it spreads southwards? That is our major problem.
- Give us the answer to it.

- Members of the Labour party will disagree with me when I say that the answer is not to sit down weakly, and wait until we are attacked. Events in the last few years have revealed that the Communists avoid an armed attack. The speeches of honorable members on both sides of the House in this debate have been based on the idea that we shall take certain action in the event of an armed attack by the Communists on Australia, or elsewhere. But the Communists do not make armed attacks. They employ the infiltration method, and that is the method we have to defeat. I go so far as to say that I do not believe that economic aid, free gifts and charity will defeat communism. We may win individual friends by the employment of those measures, but I do not think that we shall win the friendship of the powers. When all is said and done, charity is degrading to the receiver, and we shall not win the friendship of the leaders of the nations with whom we desire to be friends merely by giving them hand-outs.

speech.para: W e stall win their friendship by granting them assistance to develop their countries economically. We shall win the confidence of those peoples by showing them that we do not believe in communism. Members of the Labour party can help considerably in that respect by refraining from making excuses in this Parliament for persons who follow the Communist doctrines. That happens too frequently here. I am firmly of the opinion that we have not got the confidence, and we shall not get the confidence of the people whom we desire to be our friends when they are able to say, " We do not know whether Australians are half Communists or not. Look what happens in your National Parliament ".

We must win their confidence by proving to them that we have military strength adequate to defend ourselves in the event of an armed attack, and to assist them to defend themselves against aggression. We shall also need to guarantee them their national independence, and the only way to do so is by recognition, precept, and example. They should be placed on a similar footing to ourselves in international councils. Those measures are preferable to the granting of economic aid. But we must impress upon those people, whom we desire as friends, the fact that we are not prepared to sit meekly by while their countries are overrun, or become the satellites of a foreign power without the use of armed force. Therein lies the biggest danger to us. We may find them the satellite countries of our enemies, even though no armed attack has been launched, and they may ultimately be used for an attack upon Australia. I believe that communism will never reign supreme here. It could gain control of Australia only by the use of armed force.

Much has been said about the unfortunate situation in Indo-China. I do not blame the French for it, and I do not blame Australians for it. It appears to be an unfortunate fact that through the years, France has been the cause of tragedy to the British people. We have always had to pull France out of the difficulties in which it has involved itself. Sound advice was available to France prior to the cease-fire settlement in Indo-China and, had it been willing to take that advice, the tragedy might not have occurred. But it is too late to worry about that now. All that we can do is to learn a lesson from what has happened and make sure that a similar fate shall not befall other Asian countries. We must make certain that the excuse of nationalism., which is the big danger, the excuse of unsatisfactory government, the excuse of bad administration, the excuse of bad laws, and the excuse of the exploitation of one class by another, of which the Communists are only too ready to take advantage, cannot be advanced as reasons for changes that ultimately will bring those countries under the wing of communism. We have a duty to make our position perfectly clear to those whom we have to have as friends - India, Burma, Indonesia and Ceylon - all of which have no cause, on the ground of the suppression of nationalism, to allow communism to overrun them. We must tell these people plainly that we do . not recognize communism as a political ideology and will not tolerate it. There is no occasion for them to adopt communism. If their land laws are bad, if some classes exploit others, or if living standards arc low, they, like us in Australia, have the democratic right and the power to make necessary alterations without betraying themselves to a system that would deprive them ultimately even of the freedom and the rights that they now enjoy.

Our first obligation is to make clear to the rest of the world that communism cannot be allowed to come any closer to our shores. Then we can provide economic aid - not mere hand-outs of wheat, eggs, butter and milk - to enable our neighbours to develop their lands and raise the living conditions of their people." if they are suffering hardships. By that means we can remove the causes of dissatisfaction. Finally, by means of our own military strength, and the pacts and agreements that we make with other nations, we must secure our own defences and guarantee our neighbours security against armed attack, should that eventually come. Let us guard, not only against armed attack, but also against the greater danger of infiltration by our arch-enemy, and let us be plain about it.

talk.start.para: .- We in Australia, and the peoples of all other British democracies, have to face up to a very painful and humiliating fact at this stage of our history. The truth is that our. past has caught up with us at last in Asia and South-East Asia. We sowed the wind, and we are reaping the whirlwind of communism. What have we done for Asia over the last 200 years to entitle us to claim its allegiance and co-operation in the present crisis in that vast areas? For centuries we have dominated its economy. We have ruled it politically through reactionary governments.
- Who is this "we"?

- The democracies. We have exploited Asia's richest resources, not for the benefit of Asia, but for our own benefit. We have failed to lift the living standards of the Asians, we have suppressed their attempts at selfgovernment, and we have secretly despised their colour. We have given no encouragement to education or the improvement of standards of health. Yet now we are astonished that Asia is going Communist !

speech.para: The real lesson for the world to take from the history of Asia was set by the example of the British Labour Government which in 1948 gave self-government to India, Pakistan and Ceylon. Those nations, together with Malaya, are now the only real bastions in South-East Asia against the red flood that is sweeping down from the north. Moreover, they still remain within the British Commonwealth of Nations. As a result of the conduct of the democracies in Asia over 200 or 300 years, they have alienated the sympathies of millions of Asians, and it may be too late now for us to apply a remedy. We have done much since the end of World War II. economically, intellectually, and technically, to help the poverty-stricken areas of South-East Asia, but the Colombo plan is years too late to prevent the upsurge of communism, and it is too limited in its scope to be effective as a weapon against communism. This deadly virus was active in the poverty, wretchedness and backwardness of the people of South-East Asia long before World War [I. That is why the genuine movements towards self-government and the removal of the white man's yoke were so easily and quickly captured by the Communists and exploited in their hands even to the point of war.

The rise of nationalism in Asia has occurred 100 years later than it occurred in Europe. In the period from 1848 to 1S50 many European countries threw out their monarchies and, after much blood and error, achieved national recognition and self-government. There was no Com:munist movement then waiting hungrily in order to grab and mould genuine nationalist sentiment into Communist imperialism. But in Asia, awakening 100 years later, this has happened and the clear stream, of nationalism, which none of us would criticize, has been reddened with dire consequences to the West. This movement is dangerous because nations are having their nationalism shortcircuited or captured by communism, and also because they are being drawn into the vast vortex of the slow strangling expansion of Russian imperialism. North Korea, China, Tibet and Viet Nam are now under the red flag. The Geneva settlement was an attempt to stem the tide, but was Hanoi another Munich? Has this surrender by France only stalled off or delayed the inevitable? It is true that, under the Geneva settlement, Laos and Cambodia are to receive selfgovernment. But the terms of the surrender, which provide for elections in Viet Nam in 1955, have grave consequences for us, which the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) ably pointed out. If I understood the right honorable gentleman correctly, 13,000,000 people in north Viet Nam will be subjected to Communist propaganda for the next eighteen months. The 9,000,000 people south of the 17th parallel may be subjected to counterpropaganda, but the outcome of the election is grimly obvious. It is clear that the majority vote may favour the north and, in that event, the whole of Viet Nam, under the terms of the settlement, will be taken over by the Communists.

From then on Laos and Cambodia will be targets for a barrage of red propaganda and intrigue. A terrific war of ideas aimed at enslaving the minds of their peoples will begin. Later, Thailand and even Malaya will be bombarded with this ideological weapon that is so expertly handled by the Communists. How, then, can the southward march of the reds be halted? "What weapons are available to the anti-Communist nations to enable them to counter-attack this destroying menace? That is the question that we all ask. It is the crux of the whole debate on international affairs. What is the answer to it? All honorable members who have spoken have attempted to provide an answer. I propose four methods by which the advance of communism can be halted. Our decision on this issue will decide the future fate of Australia and will probably shape the course of history. Five years ago I said in this House, during another debate on international affairs, that the future history of the world would be written in Asia, and recent events have demonstrated the truth of my prophecy. I maintain that there are four methods of checking communism throughout the world and in South-East Asia in particular. They are the military method, the political method, the economic method, and the ideological method.

First, our defences must be modern, secure and adequate. As the honorable member for Moore (Mr. Leslie) said, we must show the peoples of South-East Asia that we will back up our words with commitments under any South-East Asia treaty. The enormous expenditure on armaments in Australia, which has totalled £600,000,000 in the last three years, is a military necessity, but I join with my colleagues in criticizing the way in which the money has been expended. It has not been spent in the most effective way. The whole of the democratic world is armed in order to defend our freedom. We have poured out many millions of pounds which, if devoted to constructive purposes, would have transformed -the face of the Western world. But Russia can wait while we continue to pour out our wealth in order to maintain our military preparedness. The Russians are a patient people and they can afford to wait for us to exhaust ourselves completely by this constant outpouring of our economic strength. Russia is determined to avoid a third world war if it can gain its objectives by bloodless absorption of small defenceless countries, or through another method, that of using others to fight its battles without involving Russian troops. Both of those methods have been frighteningly successful since 1945. In Korea the world saw for the first time an international authority, the United Nations, put an international army into the field to fight aggression. But it did so only because South Korea had appealed for military assistance. The situation in South-East Asia is different, because whereas South Korea called for assistance, and got it, no assistance has been called for in Indo-China. A military attack on communism by the Western democracies can only come if the United Nations is called into a purely national issue by the nation concerned. If that nation does not ask foi- help, then the United Nations cannot give it help. France fought its war in Indo-China for seven years alone. It was regarded by the French as a private struggle. No matter how valiantly the French may have fought it ended ingloriously. Viet Nam has been divided and probably will be entirely under Communist control by 1956. Indo-China might prove to be another Munich. We were helpless to interfere because we were not asked to help, so all this sabre-rattling by members of the Government is utterly ridiculous. They ignore the methods by which the United Nations works.

A purely military answer to communism cannot come except in a war which we start, or in resistance to Communist, aggression, if the country concerned calls us in to help. Since a full-scale Asian or global war against communism would be an atomic war of indescribable consequences to both victor and vanquished - if there were a victor - it is obvious that short-term resistance to communism must be not an offensive military resistance, but a defensive military resistance. Therefore, we have to use other methods in this short-term policy, and use them courageously, quickly, unitedly and ruthlessly. If we are successful on the political economic and ideological fronts in this struggle, then a third world war may be averted and the military offensive weapon may not be required. What we need, then, since our military arm is a defensive one only, is the maximum employment of every other arm that we have, used offensively in the time still left to avoid an atomic war of Utter annihilation for mankind which, as Mr. Churchill said, would end with the victor standing on a heap oi rubble. How disastrous it would be if we were to rely on resisting communism by military weapons alone.

I turn now to the three other kinds of offensive weapons that we can use. The first is the political weapon, which communism has used and is using with great success. Russia's diplomacy - and diplomacy is a word that covers a multiplicity of ingredients - has outstripped, outthought and out-manoeuvred western diplomacy since 1945. Our counter attack on the political front must be more intelligent and more sustained than that of the Reds if this offensive is to check communism in the South-East Asia area, or elsewhere. Included in this political approach is Western diplomacy coordinated and properly shared among America, France and the British Commonwealth. One of the weaknesses of the West is that the Western democracies are so widely separated, and that divisions, arguments and even jealousies exist between them. Russia, on the contrary, is a centralized authority ruthlessly united. That is an advantage in Russia's favour. Added to our diplomacy must be a "system of regional pacts such as were outlined in the Prime Minister's speech, like the European Defence Community, Nato, the Anzus pact, and Seato, the last of which must succeed or we shall have more trouble in South-East Asia. Democratic processes, however much we value and support them, are slow. Dictatorships, on the other hand, move fast. Another way in which we can combat communism on the political front by assisting general nationalist sentiments.

The economic weapon is another great weapon that we should also use offensively. The Communists have been using it all the time. They promised land reform, education, a united government, absence of corruption, food and work to the people of China, Korea and northern Viet Nam, and will hold out the same inducements to Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, Burma, Malaya and Indonesia. To starving, illiterate and unemployed people this is an overwhelming temptation, and the Communists have used it to great effect. Our counter-attack on the economic front, therefore, must include every economic aid that we can give to the countries needing it, even if that means a sacrifice for every one of us. Our slogan should be " Wheat instead of words ". Pood will build friendships in the East. The mighty Colombo plan is the greatest scheme that has ever been carried out by a number of nations in unison for the benefit of other nations, but its scope must be widened. Four nations have already expended a total of £500,000,000, on' the Colombo plan since 1950. A large proportion of that sum has come from the Australian Treasury. Machines, equipment, technicians and instructors have been sent to Asian countries, with which we have also exchanged students. The exchange of students is a marvellous idea which should be extended. These experts have been sent to help South-East Asian countries to improve their standard of living. What a tremendous weapon this can be. It is a tragedy that the Colombo plan was not in operation twenty years ago. At that time, however, we were sleeping between two world wars. Isolationism, materialism, selfishness and smugness dominated the whole set-up, and one of the results is that we have lost Asia.

The fourth weapon is the ideological weapon. This is another weapon that we can use offensively with tremendous effect. We are still ignorant of its true value in the fight against communism. For the first time in this Parliament, on Tuesday night, an Australian Prime Minister mentioned the ideological weapon for use by our side, for a change, and it is good to know that the potency of that weapon is at last being recognized by Australia. Never has the war of ideas assumed such significance as it assumes to-day. I have studied Communist techniques for a number of years. Such a study shows how an ideology, such as the Communist ideology, evil through it is, can capture and enslave the minds of millions of people. Hitler and Goebbels used ideological warfare, with devastating effect. The battle of ideas i" raging today everywhere in the world, and the battle grounds are the mind« and sun-its of men. Tt is a battle of beliefs and of wa.y of life, and is a corollary to the battles on the political and economic fronts. Ideas are on the march to-day across the frontiers of the world. They are conveyed over the earth by means of the radio, the press, pamphlets, books, from the platform and at street corners. The Communists work on the minds of men cleverly, passionately and persistently, wearing down their resistance and capturing the unthinking and the unprepared body, mind and soul. They have done that with millions of people since the war. Evil to-day is ruthlessly and dangerously organized in nazism, facism and communism as never before. Surely we realize by now that one powerful idea or set of beliefs, whether good or evil, if frantically or sincerely preached by one man, can set off chain reactions that can mean the destruction or the betterment of mankind, or change the course of nations and of the world. Christ was such a man. Other such men have been Napoleon, Marx, Lenin and Hitler. Our strength is in our Christian ideology striking in a counterattack at the Communist ideology on a global scale making an ideological barrier in Asian minds and hearts against the onslaught of the Communist beliefs.

talk.start.para: . - I rise to speak on the motion for the adjournment of the House, because late this afternoon the Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) thought fit to issue a public statement to the press and other instruments of publicity about the Royal Commission on Espionage in Australia and, in particular, about the problem of the moneys paid to Petrov, as has already appeared in the evidence before the commission. However, this afternoon more than one reference was made in the House to this matter. These references were followed by a public statement by the Leader of the Opposition, which I take leave to describe as not only so hysterical as to indicate a grave state of panic on his part, but also as containing, if I may borrow a term from another place, a farrago of ideas, closely following the normal Communist line about this royal commission. First, I shall do something that perhaps I should not do.
