quote.para: One of the keys to the Petrov matter is the payment to Petrov of £5,000 by the Commonwealth Government, through the agency of Security Service. The date of this payment has been fixed at April 4th last. It is plain now that the payment was made in advance before Petrov delivered' his documents.
Repeated questioning in the House has resulted in Mr. Menzies refusing all information as to when he authorized this large payment.

speech.para: I pause here to remind the House that 1 refused information because the matter was before the royal commission. That comment is, therefore, a singularly dishonest one. The statement continues-

quote.para: It is certain that he must have been a wm re of it on the night of April 13th last when he made hi3 melodramatic announcement to the House-

speech.para: A melodramatic announcement which was followed, at that time, by a unanimous vote by the Labour party !

talk.start.para: - Not at that time.

- I shall resume the sentence - when he made his melodramatic announcement, to the House and the country about Petrov seeking and being granted political asylum. The picture he then painted was one of a" man merely seeking individual freedom in a democratic State. The sinister fact was that he received £5,000 for the sale of certain documents which the Government bought for the purpose of unduly and improperly influencing people of Australia at the general election, and that the people of Australia were kept in ignorance of the " deal " until after the election.

speech.para: I again pause to say this - is this a suggestion to the Australian people that the papers were false, that they were forgeries ? The silence of the Opposition is notable and should be recorded in Hansard. The statement continues -

quote.para: Four questions arise -

item.para: Why did not Mr. Menzies inform thu people of Australia on April 13th - nine days after the payment of the £5,000 - that Petrov, who only sought democratic freedom, was paid £5,000 in addition to being granted political asylum 1

speech.para: If that statement calls for an answer, the answer is quite simple. T did not tell the House that on the 13th April, because I did not know it. The statement goes on -

item.para: Why was this vital fact kept back from the knowledge of the people of Australia from April 4th when the payment was made' until after the general election was over 1 shall answer that one. There were many vital facts not disclosed to the Australian people. For three days before [ made my statement in this House I knew the names of all the people who had been, or were, associated with the Leader of the Opposition, and whose names were mentioned in the Petrov papers, but I remained silent from the beginning to the end of the general election campaign. I should have thought that there might have been some people who would have imagined that that was playing the game pretty fairly. But now the right honorable gentleman does not, in this rhetorical fashion, ask me why I did not, half-way through the general election campaign, talk about £5,000; he does not ask me why I did not, in this House on the 13th April, tell the people the contents of the Petrov papers, because he knows that if T had done so he would not be here now. This document further asks -

Did the Commonwealth Government or the Security Service employ an intermediary or intermediaries to bargain with Petrov during 1053 and has any sum of money been paid or promised to this intermediary or intermediaries

speech.para: The answer is, I do not know. The Australian Security Service was set up by a government of which the Leader of the Opposition was a member. It was continued by my own Government. If anybody in his five wits supposes that a security service, a counter-espionage service, does not have agents who do not appear, and does not have agents who are paid for their services, it is time that he woke up to the facts of life. Of course there were such agents when the right honorable gentleman was AttorneyGeneral. Of course there are such agents * now. How does anybody outside the kindergarten suppose that a government, charged with the security of this country, is to find out what is going on in Communist circles? How do people suppose the Government is to fetter Communist activities unless it has secret agents? Of course it has them. But I suppose the new idea now is that they all ought to be volunteers. The fourth question in this document is -

item.para: What financial arrangements have been made for the maintenance of the Petrovs and what money, property or consideration have they received from the Government or the Security Service or from persons or corporations outside the Government itself?

speech.para: It is perfectly clear ; the matter has been stated before the Royal Commission on Espionage. The royal commissioners themselves have put questions about it and have offered views about it. lt is quite clear that these people are being maintained in cash and kind by this country, and we would need to be halfwits if that were not so. Here were people who, on their own showing before the royal commission, were being paid large salaries by Russia for their work. They had their own savings invested in Russia. [Extension of time granted.]"Mr. SPEAKER. - I remind the Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) that his extended time is now limited to five minutes.

talk.start.para: - That is all too short a time, but it will enable me to finish dealing with this remarkable document, because the best of it is the last. The right honorable gentleman's statement concluded -

quote.para: I believe that when the tangled skein of this matter is finally unravelled -

speech.para: He is not waiting for it to be unravelled. The royal commission is dealing with it, but that is not soon enough for him.

I believe that when the tangled skein of this matter is finally unravelled, the PetrovMenzies Letters case will rank in Australian history as an equivalent to the notorious Zinoviff Letter which was used to defeat a Labour Government in the British election of 1024 or-

And here is the cream of it! - the burning of the Reichstag which ushered in the Hitler regime in 1933. [ am not unaware of the right honorable gentleman's views. I cannot profess to follow his state of mind completely, but [ know that it is one of his theories that the whole of this matter was cunningly concealed so that it might be used for the purposes of winning an election. Therefore, I say to the House and to the country that the name of Petrov became known to me for the first time on Sunday night, the 11th April, I think, or the preceding Saturday night, lt was one of those nights, when the head of the Australian Security Service came to see m? at the Lodge in Canberra with the first two or three literally translated documents that Petrov had handed over. By the 13th April, after consultation with the Cabinet, I was announcing the position in this House, and on the following day we established a royal commission. Therefore, the whole idea that there was some cunning concealment falls to the ground. Now, since we are forced to discuss these matters, may I say that when I was told of these things on the Saturday or Sunday night at my house in Canberra, oddly enough I referred to tha Zinoviff letter. I said, " I wish this could not have happened just now, because the last thing I want to have happen is something that may look like an election stunt ". I see that the honorable member for Sturt (Mr. Makin) is pleased to smile. I say to him that if this were an election stunt I must have performed it very badly. If this were an election stunt, it was a remarkable thing for a leader of a government to say to every Government candidate at the general election, " There is to be no reference to tha Petrov case at all ".

talk.start.para: - Did they carry out your instructions ?
- Yes, they did.
- No, they did not.

- They carried out my instructions, and the fact was that, right throughout the general election campaign, knowing these names, I observed unbroken silence. Indeed, I learned about the ?5,000 payment for the first time on Sunday, the 9th May, during the course of the general election campaign. When I was asked what was to be done about it, I said that evidence should be led in its proper place and context about the payments, and the whole matter should be then examined. Those were my personal instructions on that matter. Now it is said that I should have said something about the ?5,000, and that I should have said nothing about
- The Prime Minister knows the names.
- We all know them now. There is one thing that I am bound to say about members of this Government, we can read. We have read these things in the newspapers.
- Oh!

- So, the right honorable gentleman, having enjoyed all the advantages of my silence during the last general election campaign, is now hysterically complaining because I did not produce one thing that he might have been able to use and twist on the public platform.
- Order! The right honorable gentleman's extended time has expired.

. - At last the oracle has spoken. The Prime Minister (Mr. Menzies) has been questioned about this matter day after day in this House, and has refused to answer. At last this statement has produced some answers. If he were not hysterical and panic-stricken he would have answered the questions in turn, 1, 2, 3 and 4.

- He has attempted to answer them, but he does not realize the implications of his answers. Why did not the Prime Minister inform the people about these matters before the general election? He certainly knew about them before then, but he said, " Say nothing, wait until the matter is heard by the royal commission ", so the matter was not referred to the people until after the general election. When the subject was opened, on the 10th May I think, at the Albert Hall, no expense was spared in order to get publicity for election purposes. At that time the Prime Minister knew, and counsel assisting the royal commission knew, that Petrov did not approach the Government out of love for freedom but for the consideration that has been mentioned. So it was not only the people of Australia who were deceived ; the royal commissioners were also deceived. One could always see the probability of these deceptions, but now we have heard them admitted by the Prime Minister himself. I notice him smiling; apparently he thinks it is funny. He is trying to put on an appearance of confidence. The position is that the documents were handed over by Petrov after be got his £5,000 in hard cash. The security officers knew it, aud well before the general election the Prime Minister knew it. The counsel assisting the royal commission must have known it, but the people' were deceived about it through the statement the Prime Minister made on the 13th April.

speech.para: The right honorable gentleman says that he did not make certain things public because he was so generous as not to mention documents that contained the names of members of my staff. What a wonderful man he is to adopt that viewpoint! This is the Prime Minister of Australia who, in October or November last, in a debate upon the Australian security service and alleged telephone tapping, said that it was the duty of the DirectorGeneral of Security to inform the Leader of the Opposition as well as the Prime Minister of any important developments in connexion with security. The Australian Labour party, when it was in office in 1949, established the security service as a non-political service, and it reported to the then Leader of the Opposition.

talk.start.para: - It did not.
- The right honorable gentleman said last December that it did so. The fact that it did so is recorded in .Hansard, and the right honorable gentleman knows it.
- Rubbish !
- Order ! If tho House does not maintain order, I shall have to name those who offend.

- The right honorable gentleman denies it, but it appears in black and white in . Hansard. . The honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) and the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron) raised the matter upon privilege. The Prime Minister said that it was the duty of the Director-General of Security to inform the Leader of the Opposition as well as the Prime Minister of such matters. Did the right honorable gentleman do so on this occasion ? No ! He remained silent. He did not perform his duty, and he prevented the DirectorGeneral of Security from performing his duty. The right honorable gentleman says to me, " I did not tell the people of Australia about paying the £5,000 to Petrov because I was good enough npt to mention the fact that the names of members of your staff appeared on a certain document!" It was a sale of documents. Petrov's object was political asylum. It is plain, on the evidence, that he was determined to obtain asylum eighteen months before he did. He began to collect documents and I have no doubt that, if those documents had been made available, we would have discovered a lot of things that have not been made known to the people of Australia. The fact that at the glamourized demonstration at the Albert Hall the information was not placed before the people shows that the Prime Minister was deceiving the people. If the right honor- . able gentleman wishes to talk about my staff, let me remind him. of this fact- r
- Ah!
- Order ! The honorable member for Henty must not interject.
- I did not say a word.
- Order ! The honorable member made a noise.

- If facts which were detrimental to the trustworthiness of these men and not merely names in documents had been revealed, did not duty and decency require the Prime Minister to inform the Leader of the Opposition of those facts?
- Be careful.
- I did not hear about the O'sullivan matter until the day before that man was dismissed.
- Be careful.

- I am being careful. The right honorable gentleman is not being careful. Each of the matters that has been raised forms the basis of a proper question. The right honorable gentleman did not know all of the facts at a certain stage, but he knew them in sufficient time to have informed the Leader of the Opposition of them. He allowed the people to remain under an impression that was created in a dramatic way. The Prime Minister objects to the use of the word " melodramatic", but that night he introduced this matter in a melodramatic way. The right honorable gentleman, with the approval of Cabinet, had made up his mind by lunch time on a certain day to make his statement. I did not leave Canberra until 5.30 p.m. on that day. Not a word was spoken to me about the fact that a statement would be made, and I did not hear about it until 9 o'clock that night in Sydney. The Prime Minister's statement was not answered that night. I had to make a short press statement, and I stand by that statement in every respect. To the best ofmy belief, it is correct to say - the Prime Minister's statement confirms it and the people of Australia now know - that at the general election, although the Prime Minister and the security service knew that the money had been paid by the Government in respect of this information and these documents, the people were allowed to believe that nothing of that kind had happened. It was not until after the election that the matter was mentioned. The questions that were asked by the honorable member for East Sydney, and my own questions to-night, have elicited a response which, in ray opinion, is disastrous for the Government.
- Order !

- The Prime Minister has said that Government candidates did not mention the matter during the election campaign. It was mentioned in nearly every electorate in Australia. The Treasurer (Sir ArthurFadden) made public reference to it, and circulars were distributed in some of the electorates. The Prime Minister does not do these things directly, but he does them through such people as the Treasurer. This matter was placed before the people of Australia, and it was an important factor in the result of the election. It altered the result of the election in half a dozen electoral divisions. We are in a satisfactory position at last, because a few more of the facts have been made known to the people of Australia. It is a tangled skein, which must be unravelled and which shall be unravelled.
